Waste-minimized, solvent-free and continuous flow synthesis of α-ketoamides from aryl methyl ketones using recyclable CuBr2 catalyst, via bromo intermediate Mouzma Mhate Methodology 1 Amit Gautam Methodology 1 Kankanala Naveen Kumar Methodology V. Ravichandiran Writing – original draft Sharada Prasanna Swain Visualization Writing – review & editing ⁎ Department of Medicinal Chemistry and Centre for Marine Therapeutics (CMT), National Institute of Pharmaceutical Education and Research-Kolkata, 168, Maniktala Main Road, Kolkata 700054, India Department of Medicinal Chemistry and Centre for Marine Therapeutics (CMT) National Institute of Pharmaceutical Education and Research-Kolkata 168, Maniktala Main Road Kolkata 700054 India Department of Medicinal Chemistry and Centre for Marine Therapeutics (CMT), National Institute of Pharmaceutical Education and Research-Kolkata, 168, Maniktala Main Road, Kolkata 700054, India ⁎ Corresponding author. 1 These authors contributed equally. The α-ketoamide functional groups are abundant in a variety of drug molecules such as tacrolimus (immunosuppressant), boceprevir (antiviral), telaprevir (antiviral), and varespladib (anti-inflammatory). Molecular oxygen is an environmentally benign and cost-effective oxidant. The Solvent-free synthesis reduces environment pollution and cost of pharmaceuticals manufacturing. A new copper(II) bromide catalysed method for the synthesis of α-ketoamides from aryl ketones and amines, in presence of molecular oxygen, in a solvent-free condition is reported. This is the first copper(II)bromide-catalysed synthesis of α-ketoamides which proceeds via a bromo intermediate, in comparison to traditional copper(I)-catalysed reaction (enamine intermediate). The CuBr2 catalyst was recovered and successfully recycled. The reaction was performed in a continuous flow reactor to reduce the time of reaction (residence time: 20min). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Data availability All data generated during this study are included in this article and supplementary information. 1 Introduction The α-ketoamide motif is present in a wide variety of drug molecules such as tacrolimus (immunosuppressant), boceprevir (antiviral), telaprevir (antiviral), varespladib (anti-inflammatory) etc (Fig. 1 ) [1]. Several natural products contain α-ketoamide moieties [2]. They are also used as a suitable precursor for synthesis of several organic compounds [3,4]. The classical methods for the synthesis of α-ketoamides are oxidation of arylacetamides [5], oxidative amidation-diketonization of alkynes [6], double carbonylation of aryl halides [7,8], reaction of formamides with α-oxocarboxylic acids [9,10], oxidation of α-hydroxyamides and α-aminoamides [11,12], amidation of a-keto acids and a-keto acyl halides [13,14], and oxidative coupling of aryl acetaldehydes with anilines [15]. Ketones are versatile organic compounds, and are easily transformed to different functional groups. Ketones can undergo oxidative transformations by Pd [16], and photocatalysis [17]. Copper is widely used for several organic reactions, and synthesis of pharmaceuticals, as it has high earth-abundance, excellent physical and chemical properties, and low cost [18]. Aryl ketones 1 were directly converted to α-ketoamides in presence of copper(I) bromide, N-iodosuccinimide (NIS) and O2 as an oxidant (Scheme 1 ) [19]. The other reported copper catalysed oxidative methods for conversion of aryl ketones to α-ketoamides utilize (i) copper(II) acetate, H2O2 and I2 [20] ; (ii) Cu2O nanoparticles in presence of O2 [21]; and (iii) copper complexes [22]. Aryl ketones can also be transformed to α-ketoamides in presence of I2 in DMSO [23], I2 and O2 [24], I2 and t-butyl hydroperoxide (TBHP) [25], sodium iodide (NaI) and TBHP [26], NIS and TBHP [27], n Bu4NI and TBHP [28], O2 and photocatalyst [29]. In most of the cases, strong oxidants such as H2O2 [20], TBHP [25–28] or Iodine containing reagents [20,23–28] are used. Peroxides are considered as very reactive compounds, as the oxygen-oxygen bond in peroxides may be cleaved to generate very reactive free radicals. So, the use of peroxides raises safety concerns in lab and bulk synthesis [30a]. I2 or iodine containing reagents should be quenched with reagents like sodium thiosulfate and ascorbic acid, prior to discarding the effluent to environment [30b]. Liang and co-workers [19] have reported synthesis of α-ketoamides 5 catalysed by copper(I) bromide and NIS, in presence of O2 as an oxidant (Scheme 1). The reaction proceeds via enamine intermediate 3, followed by iodination with NIS. Molecular oxygen is the source of both oxygen atoms in the desired α-ketoamide product. Herein, we report copper(II) bromide catalysed synthesis of α-ketoamides from aryl ketones, in presence of molecular oxygen in a solvent-free condition (Scheme 1). This is the first copper(II)bromide-catalysed synthesis of α-ketoamides. The mechanism of this reaction (bromo compound as the intermediate) is different from the earlier reported copper(I)-catalysed reaction (enamine pathway). A new mechanism for the conversion of ketones to α-keto amides is proposed. This method avoids the use of reactive peroxides and iodine containing reagents, and no solvent was used for conducting the reaction. The CuBr2 can also be recovered and reused. Whereas, the catalysts were not recycled in the reported method using CuBr and CuI [19]. Hence, the proposed method has significant improvement (E-factor: 0.65) over the recent reported green process (E-factor: 1.26) [19] for the synthesis of α-ketoamides from aryl ketones (Scheme 1), as calculated in a reported method [31]. The reaction was also tried in a flow reactor to reduce the time of reaction (residence time 20min). Use of molecular oxygen as an oxidant and a source of oxygen is well accepted in academic research and industrial bulk manufacturing, as it is an environmentally benign reagent and cost-effective too [32]. The design of benign chemicals and waste prevention for the synthesis of organic compounds, pharmaceuticals are part of 12 principles of green chemistry [33]. Our lab is working on the development of new synthetic methods for the synthesis of active pharmaceutical ingredients (API) using green chemistry principles [34]. The solvent-free reactions reduce the waste in pharmaceutical API manufacturing. Pharmaceutical industries are devoting major efforts to replace hazardous solvents, reduce the volume of solvents and develop reactions in a solvent-free condition [35]. This will reduce environment pollution and cost of pharmaceuticals. Our lab has developed a solvent-free Mannich reaction and its application for the synthesis of ranitidine (a drug for treatment of acid reflux and stomach ulcer) [34a]. The use of water as a green solvent and use of recyclable catalysts have significantly increased in organic synthesis [36]. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials Unless otherwise mentioned, all the solvents, reactants and reagents were purchased from commercial suppliers and used without further purification. Acetophenones, CuBr2 and amines were purchased from TCI, Chennai, India. DMSO, ethyl acetate, n-hexane and toluene were procured from Signa/Merck, India. 2.2 Methods Standard procedure for synthesis of α-keto amides in a batch process: Acetophenones 1 (1.0 eq., 3.0mmol), amine compounds 2 (1.5 eq., 4.5mmol) were stirred in a round bottom flask. CuBr2 (0.1 equiv, 0.3mmol) was added, oxygen balloon was inserted via a needle to the flask and heated at 50°C for 12-18h. The reaction was monitored by TLC, for complete conversion of starting material. Ethyl acetate (10.0mL) was added to the reaction mass, filtered the catalyst, washed the organic layer with water (5.0mL) twice. The ethyl acetate layer was evaporated under vacuum. The crude mass was purified by silica gel column chromatography, the desired α-ketoamide compounds were eluted using 20-25% ethyl acetate in n-hexane. 3 Results and Discussion As part of our research for the synthesis of α-amino keto compounds, we attempted the CuBr2- catalysed amination in presence of molecular oxygen, as reported by MacMillan and co-workers (Scheme 2 ) [37]. McMillan used propiophenones to get α-amino keto compounds. Whereas, when we used acetophenone, and the product was different from the expected α-amino ketone 10. The expected α-amino keto compound 10 was not obtained, and the isolated compound was characterized to be α-ketoamide (5aa) [19]. The presence of a peak with chemical shift value δ 165.5 in 13C NMR, confirms the presence of the carbonyl group of amide functional group. The reported CuBr catalysed synthesis of α-ketoamide requires NIS along with molecular oxygen. Whereas, this reaction does not require any iodine containing reagent. We tried to explore this reaction by optimizing the reaction conditions, solvents, mole ratio of reagents and catalysts. The initial reaction was carried out using 1.0 equiv of ketone 1a with 2.0 equiv. of amine 2a and 0.2 equiv of CuBr2 (0.2 equiv.) in DMSO at 50 °C (Table 1 , entry 1). The reduction of amine ratio to 1.5 equiv, did not reduce the yield (Table 1, entry 2). Whereas, the use of 1.1 equiv of amine generated the product in lower yield (Table 1, entry 3). But, the complete conversion of starting material did not happen, when non polar solvents like toluene (Table 1, entry 4,5) and ethyl acetate (Table 1, entry 6) were used. The reaction in polar aprotic solvent such as dimethyl acetamide (Table 1, entry 7) generated the desired compound with 81% yield, like the reaction in DMSO. The same reaction was carried out in a solvent-free condition, using oxygen balloon, produced the ketoamide compound in similar yield. The yield was reduced to 51%, when higher ratio of acetophenone (2.0 equiv.) was used (Table 1, entry 8). The change of catalyst to CuCl2 (Table 1, entry 9) led to ketoamides with lower yield (15%). The reaction using Cu(OAc)2 (Table 1, entry 10) and CuSO4 (Table 1, entry 11) produced α-keto amide in trace amount. The reaction using other oxidants such as H2O2 (Table 1, entry 12) and TBHP (Table 1, entry 13) generated α-keto amide 5aa with lower yield, in comparison to O2 (Table 1, entry 3). As peroxides generate reactive free radicals, and considering safety parameters, O2 was chosen as an oxidant for further studies. Our next study was to perform the reaction in a solvent-free condition and it was successful (Table 1, entry 14,15). But the yield was not promising (68%), as the reaction was carried out in open air condition, instead of using oxygen. The reaction using oxygen balloon (1 atm pressure) yielded the ketoamide 5aa with 83% yield (Table 1, entry 16). Whereas, the reduction of CuBr2 to 0.1 equiv. (Table 1, entry 17) provided 5aa in similar yield (82%). But, there was a significant reduction in yield when 5mol% of CuBr2 was used (Table 1, entry 18). The increase in ratio of acetophenone to 2.0 equiv reduced the yield (Table 1, entry 19). The optimized reaction condition was found to be the reaction of 1.0 equiv. of acetophenone with 1.5 equiv. of piperidine at 50 °C, catalysed by CuBr2 (0.1 equiv.) in presence of molecular oxygen (Table 1, entry 17). The substrates scope of the reaction was studied. The reaction of piperidine with acetophenone gave desired α-keto amide 5ab with 75% yield (Table 2 , entry 2). Acetophenones with an electron withdrawing group such as nitro group (Table 2, entry 3) produced the α-ketoamide 5bb with excellent yield. The presence of an electron donating group (OMe) on acetophenone generated ketoamides with 70-82% yield (Table 2, entries 4 and 5), which are lower than 4-nitro acetophenone (91%). The halo substituted acetophenones were well tolerated (Table 2, entries 6-8) in the reaction condition. Further reactions taking 4-methyl substituted acetophenone (Table 2, entry 9), bicyclic aryl ketone (Table 2, entries 10 and 11) and five membered ketone (Table 2, entry 12 and 13) also brought out ketoamides with excellent yields. Then, we attempted the reaction with different amines such as ethyl 4-piperidinecarboxylate (Table 2, entry 14). But it gave ketoamide 5ac with 53% yield, and this could be due to lower nucleophilicity of the amine 2c, which is bearing an electron withdrawing group. Unfortunately, pyrrolidine could produce ketoamide with 56% yield only (Table 2, entry 15). The use of bicyclic amine 2e generated ketoamide 5ae with 68% yield (Table 2, entry 16), and the formation of rotamers were observed in NMR spectrum. The reaction was not successful when primary amines such as cyclohexyl amine and aniline were used. Flow chemistry is a green technology used for the synthesis of pharmaceuticals, and applied for safe operation of hazardous chemicals, unstable intermediates, reduction of impurity and time of reaction [38]. We planned to use a flow reactor to reduce the time of this reaction. We started the reaction in a flow reactor (10mL reactor volume) at rt with residence time (t res) 10.0 min (Table 3 , entry 1), flow rate 1.0mL/min., and the starting material 1a was not consumed. Then, we performed the reactions at 50 °C, with residence time 5-15 min (Table 3, entries 2-4) to get the yield up to 59%. The reaction at 50 °C with residence time 20min., provided the desired product 5aa in 75% yield (Table 1, entry 5). The optimized condition (Table 1, entry 5) was applied to other substrates (Fig. 2 ). The compounds 5aa, 5ab, 5bb, 5cb, 5eb, 5gb, 5hb, 5ae were successfully synthesized (Fig. 2) in 68-91% yields, with a flow rate of 500µL/min., and residence time of 20min. Copper (II) bromide generates enolate intermediate 11 (Scheme 3 ), as described by Ostrum [39] and MacMillan [37]. Then, it facilitates α-bromination and lead to formation of bromo intermediate compound 12. The amine compound 2 act as a nucleophile and reacts with bromo compound 12 to form the amine intermediate 13. Molecular oxygen promotes regeneration of copper (II) bromide catalyst by oxidation of the generated copper (I) bromide in presence of HBr. The oxidation of copper (I) bromide to copper (II) bromide by molecular oxygen is already reported by MacMillan [37]. The further bromination of α-keto amine 13 by copper (II) bromide generates bromo compound 14, which undergoes elimination to give iminium intermediate 15. The bromination of α-carbonyl amines is using N-bromo succinimide (NBS) is reported in literature [40]. We report the bromination of α-carbonyl amines by CuBr2. The formation of bromo intermediate 14 was confirmed by mass spectrometric analysis (appearance of a peak at 296.0537). Iminium compound may undergo aerobic oxidation to provide desired α-keto amide compound 5. Aerobic oxidation of α-keto iminium compound to α-keto amide is described by Ahmed [41] and Guo [24]. A control experiment was conducted in absence of oxygen (in presence of nitrogen) to prove that molecular oxygen is required for oxidation of copper(I) bromide to copper(II) bromide, and α-keto iminium to α-keto amide (Scheme 4 ). The desired α-keto amide 5 was not obtained in absence of oxygen, which proves that oxygen is required for this reaction. The first step of the reaction mechanism is formation of bromo compound 12. We carried out reaction of readily available phenacyl bromide (12) with amine 2 in presence of CuBr2 and O2 (Scheme 4). The desired α-ketoamide was isolated and characterized. The proposed intermediate 13 was prepared, and heated at 50 °C in DMSO in presence of CuBr2 and O2. The expected ketoamide 5 was formed as characterized 1H and 13C NMR studies (Scheme 4). The formation of bromo compound 14 and iminium compound 15 was confirmed by high resolution mass analysis. A peak at 296.0537 and 217.1410 in mass spectrum, confirms the presence of intermediate 14, 15, respectively, in the crude reaction mass. The compound 1a was reacted with CuBr2, and the intermediate 12 was isolated (Scheme 4e 4), by following the reported literature.37 The appearance of a peak with chemical shift value δ 31.16 in 13C NMR, confirms the formation of bromo intermediate 12. The standard procedure for work-up of this reaction is addition of ethyl acetate to the reaction mass and filtration of catalyst. After drying the catalyst, it was recycled once, and the reaction was tried using the recovered catalyst. The recovery of catalyst was 80%. The reaction using the recovered CuBr2 catalyst provided the desired α-keto amide 5aa with similar yield, in comparison to the reaction catalysed by the fresh catalyst. 4 Conclusions A CuBr2-catalysed solvent-free, green method for the synthesis of α-ketoamides is developed. Molecular oxygen oxidises the CuBr to CuBr2 and the iminium intermediate to α-ketoamide. The reaction happens in a mild condition at 50 °C, and is easy to operate. A new mechanism is proposed for this reaction. The CuBr2 catalyst was recovered from the reaction mass and recycled for further reactions. The reaction was successfully performed in a flow reactor, to reduce the time of reaction (residence time: 20min.). This method is well tolerated with variety of substrates and could be applied for the synthesis of α-ketoamide containing API. CRediT authorship contribution statement Mouzma Mhate: Methodology. coredata.dc:description: The α-ketoamide functional groups are abundant in a variety of drug molecules such as tacrolimus (immunosuppressant), boceprevir (antiviral), telaprevir (antiviral), and varespladib (anti-inflammatory). Molecular oxygen is an environmentally benign and cost-effective oxidant. The Solvent-free synthesis reduces environment pollution and cost of pharmaceuticals manufacturing. A new copper(II) bromide catalysed method for the synthesis of α-ketoamides from aryl ketones and amines, in presence of molecular oxygen, in a solvent-free condition is reported. This is the first copper(II)bromide-catalysed synthesis of α-ketoamides which proceeds via a bromo intermediate, in comparison to traditional copper(I)-catalysed reaction (enamine intermediate). The CuBr2 catalyst was recovered and successfully recycled. The reaction was performed in a continuous flow reactor to reduce the time of reaction (residence time: 20min).
coredata.dc:title: Waste-minimized, solvent-free and continuous flow synthesis of α-ketoamides from aryl methyl ketones using recyclable CuBr2 catalyst, via bromo intermediate
